headline: GOP delays House vote on 'compromise' immigration bill
subHeadline: Republicans regroup after first immigration bill is voted down in the House; reaction and analysis on 'The Five.'

utterances.speaker: DANA PERINO, CO-HOST
utterances.sentences: Hello, everyone. I'm Dana Perino along with Kimberly Guilfoyle, Juan Williams, Jesse Watters, and Greg Gutfeld. It's 5 o'clock in New York City, and this is "The Five." Several big developments on immigration, house lawmakers rejecting a conservative bill introduced by house judiciary committee chairman Bob Goodlatte. As for what's being called the compromise bill drafted by the Republican leadership, the vote on that is being delayed until tomorrow to try to shore up more support. Over at the White House, President Trump is continuing to going after Democrats after ending the controversial practice of separating migrant families.

utterances.speaker: PRESIDENT DONALD TRUMP
utterances.sentences: My administration is also acting swiftly to address the illegal immigration crisis on the southern border, loopholes in our immigration laws all supported by extremist open border Democrats. People are suffering because of the Democrats. So, we've created and they've created and they've let it happen, a massive child smuggling industry. The worse everything looks, they think the better they're going to do with respect to the blue wave, which is turning out frankly to be a red wave if you look at the poll. The Democrats are causing tremendous damage and destruction and lives by not doing something about this. And they know that.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: The president reiterating that he doesn't want to separate children from their parents but is still sticking by his zero tolerance policy.

utterances.speaker: TRUMP
utterances.sentences: If we took zero tolerance away, you would be overrun. You'd have millions of people pouring through our border. If you took zero tolerance away, everybody would come right now. They'd be getting their little belongings, unfortunately, and they would be heading up. You would be -- you would have a run on this country the likes of which nobody has ever seen.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: And First Lady Melania Trump making a surprise visit to a detention center housing migrant children along the border in Texas. But her fashion choice appears to be overshadowing a trip. The first lady wearing a jacket bearing the words, I really don't care, do you? A spokesperson responding to media speculation saying it's a jacket. There was no hidden message. Having lived through mission accomplished for many years, I am sympathetic with the White House. Obviously, was not intended to show any sort of message. But back to the important thing at hand. Kimberly, the Republicans said we don't have enough support for either of these bills. We have to stop and try to figure out a way to do that. There's going to be a conference. I think they're meeting right now behind closed doors. This is the third behind closed doors meeting they have had on this week. What do you think will happen and will that vote get enough -- that vote get enough support tomorrow?

utterances.speaker: KIMBERLY GUILFOYLE, CO-HOST
utterances.sentences: I think, look, obviously, I'm for behind closed doors meeting. Hopefully they're working on it and they're building some, you know, coalition there. Getting some consensus to move. Obviously, they can tell that the American people want some resolution of this. The president would like something to come forward. However, I think it might be a little bit of a struggle because there is some pretty, you know, differing opinions and viewpoints and he also has his base he's thinking about. He has, obviously, this issue which is on a tremendous amount of political attention. You've got midterm elections coming up. You know he campaigned on getting things done and making sure that he was going to make positive changes. He's somebody who is very good at getting deals done. So, you know, I'm optimistic and that he's going to get involved in this and try very hard to push on it. He's got to get the votes. Right now they don't have them, but it doesn't mean that they won't get them. And as for the fashion statement, I mean, it's a jacket. Let's relax.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: Jesse, the fact that the conservative bill passed today. The president said he supported both bills. But now that that one has failed, if it's possible if the president said I am for this bill, I will give you cover on this bill, you should vote for it, that it could pass?

utterances.speaker: JESSE WATTERS, CO-HOST
utterances.sentences: The president can only do so much with the house. I mean, the dirty little secret is the open borders, cheap labors, big business lobby has a lot of power over Republicans. And we're not going to get any help from the Democrats at all. So, there's just no consensus and there's nothing that's ever going to be done on immigration. I don't even think after the midterms it's ever going to get done. And the Democrats when they had a super majority under Barack Obama they did nothing on immigration. The Democrats just want to blame Republicans for the issue and score political point. But I don't think this whole separating families thing is a big winner for the Democrats. I think they've overplayed their hands. They've exposed themselves as complete open borders advocates. The president completely shut the deal down. He's keeping families together. Now they're complaining that they're abusing children. Melania goes down and now they're complaining about the jacket. You're never going to get a win on this issue. I think like a normal issue like gas prices, healthcare, jobs, those are the things that actually affect the lives of everyday Americans. Yes, migrant families will tug at your heart strings and makes you feel sad and you want to find a solution, but it's not going to be a driving issue for regular voters in the midterm elections.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: And, Greg, I had Congressman Burgess on the 2 o'clock show today.

utterances.speaker: GREG GUTFELD, CO-HOST
utterances.sentences: Good for you.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: I'm getting to a good point. He's part of the -- he's a Texas congressman.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Yeah.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: . a doctor, a conservative guy, he wanted both bills to pass. He decided to vote for them. And he's on something called the immigration reform caucus. And I said, in the caucus do you actually have Democrats that are willing to come to the table on this? And he said no. That he has tried talking to them and that he can't get anywhere. And he does think that they just want to be obstructionist.  Gregg: Yeah, I don't think it's about the kids. It's always going to be about Trump. This is about 2016, and it's about 2018 and 2020. It's about elections. We know that what Trump does will never be enough. It will be seen as even less humane than what was before. So, the liberal opinion is this. If you split up families you're a Nazi, whether the family is pretend or not you're a Nazi. But if you keep them together you're worse than a Nazi. So they actually have no solution. Liberals become paralyzed when faced with having to solve a problem. And the media puts some notion before facts so they just contribute to it. So now you're having critics of Trump actually arguing against their own wishes. So, now, OK, we're going to keep the families together, or the pseudo families together, or whatever, you should be happy that they're now detained. Now that's awful. I have to give credit to CNN because I always bash CNN. But I said yesterday that a lot of these problems existed under Obama and they were really, really bad problems, but the media never talks about it. Finally, I think it was senator -- I can't remember the name of the senator -- Baldwin? But, Brook Baldwin asked a very simple question. Can we throw that?

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: Yes, sure, absolutely.

utterances.speaker: UNINDENTIFIED FEMALE
utterances.sentences: Here's a question for Democrats. So many people in this country are certainly outraged by the K-do's, and the thermal blankets, and the facilities housing these kids, you know. They were all there in 2014 under President Obama. And my question to you, Senator Baldwin, is did you speak up against them then?

utterances.speaker: SEN. TAMMY BALDWIN (D), WISONSIN
utterances.sentences: You know, on this issue that we get into a moment where we're making progress and then when it stalls, we turn around. I think we all need to continue to be focused on it and press it through.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: So she just exposed how political this is.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Was that English? I didn't understand a word she said.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Yeah, yeah. They didn't care before.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: And, actually -- and before, Juan, Chuck Schumer has voted for wall funding before. And a lot of the money that is being talked about right now in the current bill that's under consideration is $25 billion, so not necessary for all new wall. A lot of it is to shore up and to approve parts of the wall that we already have. But he says now that he can't support it.

utterances.speaker: JUAN WILLIAMS, CO-HOST
utterances.sentences: Right. And remember, there was a deal between Democrats and the president. The president was one who backed out of that deal a long time ago. So, I think, to the contrary, what Greg was saying, I think you have a situation where you have evidence here, Republicans have the majority in the house, Republicans have the majority in the senate, and what you have is fights among Republicans that are continuing to paralyze their ability to pass any legislation. I think that's what we're seeing writ large today. Republicans can't get it together and they have people literally fighting on the house floor. Congressman Mark Meadow of the freedom caucus going face-to-face, pointing, moving away, coming back to continue to fight with speaker.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: He said he was just being passionate.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: Yeah, right. So, what you have here is a situation where the president, I think, contrary to what I'm hearing here is, the president likes the idea of saying it's the Democrats' fault. Remember, the president said this is the law. I can't do anything about it. It's up to the congress. Then he turns tail and signs executive order and, guess what, undoes it.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: But then.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Because you know how soft executive orders are because everything Obama did was executive orders, and then Trump just got rid of them. That's why you have congress take care of immigration law.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: If you don't let me talk I guess you won't have a show. But I'm just saying you have the president as the one who've said, oh, I can't do anything about it. It's up to them. And he's the one who literally changes course and has to do it. He's back as we've saw last night in Minnesota to try to demonize not only the Democrats but the immigrants again. He said I'm strong. I'm going to enforce these borders. These people will run over the border. What is he talking about? Does anybody say, hey, Mr. President, stop lying?

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: Well, here's the thing, Kimberly, that regardless of what happens on this particular bill tomorrow it still has to pass the senate.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.sentences: Right.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: And this issue is not going away. It fuels a lot of passion and people feel really strongly about it on all sides. What do you think is the strategy to try to actually solve the problem and not deal with the politics of this? Both sides are playing it.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.sentences: Of course they are, right? That's an honest statement and a reflection of what's going on. But, nevertheless, I do believe that the president does want to do something about this. He likes to see things and say there's a problem here, I'm going to be the guy who's going to fix it. So, would he like congress to be able to act? Yes. So it's long lasting change from a legislative perspective versus an executive order like Jesse points out that can be undone? Yes. He's at a rally. He's not demonizing anybody. I mean, let's not sugar coat the issue. You're not supposed to break the law and come into the country illegally. Nevertheless, we have to deal with this issue and with children coming over in a compassionate way but still enforce the law. This nation, this country has a right to have its laws upheld and have them observed, and there's policies and procedures in place. We welcome immigrants. All of us have background as immigrants, and family members that have come over here, great. God bless, OK? We embrace people. This is a country that is very humanitarian. This is a president who cares deeply about families and about children. He's proved that over and over again. Give him the opportunity to fix it.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: The President of the United States, commander-in-chief, solemn responsibility is protection of the country.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: Yeah. But he's not supposed to go around calling people an infestation, animals, criminals, rapists.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Peter Fonda, yesterday, did you, Juan. You thought Peter Fonda just misused some words.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: No, no. You're the one that likes to say we should -- don't take Trump's word so seriously. Look at his actions here, Greg. His actions are just horrific. And that's why Americans are saying.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.sentences: He just fixed the issue. He just fixed the issue.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Well, now they're putting together. They're being detained together, but yet that's horrific. You know what's interesting, the irony here, is that it took Donald Trump for these hypocrites to finally act or pretend to act. If they had another four years of a liberal president, or a Democrat, the scandals of unaccompanied minors would have continued. Just the way it did under Obama. But now they care. Why? Because there's a Republican. And it wouldn't matter if it's Trump. If it was Marco Rubio, if it was Jeb Bush, they'd still be demonizing and it's not the same. Both sides are not politicizing it. It's on the same level. It is so out of proportion on the left's side because they have ignored the suffering of children for so long until now. But they don't care about Chicago. They care about 2,000 kids. We care about 2,000 kids. We care about all the kids. Pro-lifers care about all the kids, Juan, can you shake your head.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: No, because it's so -- so absurd. You know what you have here.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Donate to Planned Parenthood.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: You have a situation here where the president is the one who put in place the policy. First, it was the dreamers. Remember he undid the dreamers. Then he changed the policy with regard to separating children from parents. And you act like, oh, it's the Democrats. These are actions taken by President Trump.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Read the Washington Post piece from 2016.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Read the Washington Post from 2016 about the children that were abused that were let in under Obama.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: You know what the policy is that started? It's catch and release, Juan. That's what attracts all of this migration. And when you get rid of catch and release, you have a zero tolerance policy.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: This is like Trump saying everybody is going to rush over the border.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: If you build a wall and you don't do the catch and release, then that's why have you border security.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Senator Rob Portman exposed this in 2016.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: Oh, yeah.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.sentences: Juan, if the Democrats take over Congress, are they going to be able to solve this issue?

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: I hope so. Because one of the realities here.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.sentences: Well, they didn't do it before when they had control of both. They didn't do anything after Obama.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: What are you talking about? It was under President Bush in '06 that Republicans defeated an attempt at comprehensive immigration reform.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.sentences: Oh, no.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Bottom line, you don't want border security. Bottom line.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: It doesn't matter.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: You want open borders, Juan, just admit it.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: You know what? I can say horrible things about you.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: That's not horrible, that's a policy difference.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: That's not true.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: We believe in border security.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: . that's why I say it's horrible.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: . you don't.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: Here's the reality. Most people who come.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: That's the reality.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: . illegally are not crossing any border by foot. They're flying.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Juan, if you want border security, you have the TSA at the airport, but you want open border on the south makes no sense.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: I don't want any open border. I'm just telling you this is all about political.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: This is great TV. Keep it going. People love this stuff.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: Wait. All right. President Trump slams Democratic elitism, his fiery remarks, a little but even more than that, next.

utterances.speaker: TRUMP
utterances.sentences: Was that a man or a woman because he needs a haircut more than I do. I couldn't tell. He needs a haircut.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: That's our Donald. Last night's rally was nothing new, the crowd loved him. The people who already hate him will just hate him more. And the media pats itself on the head for not covering it while secretly watching Fox News. Too bad, they totally missed an opportunity to call him Hitler. So, for the bias-impaired here's news: Trump just reduced the risk of nuclear war. He also got remains of 200 U.S. soldiers back from North Korea just a week after the issue was raised. He's bringing in record-low unemployment, helping women and minorities most. He's addressed trade imbalances as our GDP climbs higher. So, if he's monster, he might be the worst monster ever -- meaning, not a monster at all. That's why optimism is high: 95 percent of manufacturers have a positive company outlook. It's good news. Even if the elites deny it. And about those elites:

utterances.speaker: TRUMP
utterances.sentences: Do you ever notice they always call the other side, and they do this -- the elite. The elite. Why are they elite? I have a much better apartment than they do.

utterances.speaker: TRUMP
utterances.sentences: I'm smarter than they are. I'm richer than they are. I became president and they didn't.

utterances.speaker: TRUMP
utterances.sentences: And I'm representing the greatest, smartest, most loyal, best people on earth: the deplorables. Remember that?

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: That's key. Now bragging is never appealing, but he's not wrong that by wealth he's an elitist, yet, he's still embraced by working classes. No wonder the De Niro's, the Madonna's, the Depp's, the Fonda's all unravel. Trump is richer than them all, but closer to the street than they are. How can that be? The answer is he makes promises and fights to keep them. And besides, for you deplorables at the rally the outrage celebrity class will always deem you to be the uncool kids. Trump defends you against the jerks. So, it's not about wealth or apartments. It's about speaking up for people that the media celebrity complex snickers at. And it's why when everything seems to be working out those snickers seem truly from Mars.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Did you like that, Dana?

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: Yeah, in the milky way.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Are you like those silly little puns. Is Donald Trump a bit like your rich uncle always telling your -- why can't your buddy get a haircut?

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: I grew up in Wyoming where it's like tight short haircut. My Aunt Donna.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: . is the one who does the haircuts in the kitchen every couple weeks there. You know what I was thinking about today who might -- I'm trying to go one other person who had this ability. Someone who's successful, wealthy, a celebrity, but who is still considered blue collar.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Me.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: I came up with Clint Eastwood.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Oh, yeah.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: And I think it's partly because of the art that he chose. The way that he chose to -- the movies he directed. The how he acted. The things that he did. There's not many others.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Yeah, he speaks the language, Jesse. And it's like -- but I want to go back to the haircut thing.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Sure.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Because I believe the haircut thing is about being presentable for a job. That's how a salesman -- it's like get a haircut, Jesse.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Clean it up, Watters. Yeah. But he's also a man's man. And, you know, you speak about these man buns and you can mock a man bun now in 2018.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.sentences: Greg does.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: We still can do that. And the rest of the people are afraid to talk about other people's appearance because they may be being accused of being insensitive. Donald Trump has never been afraid of being called insensitive, right. So, he's like the common man for a few reasons. One, he's dealt with contractors all his life. Remember, he's like, I can smell a contractor. But it's true. You know, as a real estate developer you deal with the pipe fitters, the masons, the electrical engineers, and he's great at that. And he also eats fast food not for a photo op because he actually likes it.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Yeah.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.sentences: Like us.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: He speaks in a blunt, brash style that connects with the average American. And, to be honest, he has that aspirational celebrity. For many generations, people and the rest of the country looked up to Donald Trump. They like the women he was around. They liked the planes. They liked the style. They liked the jets. And if you want to become rich in America, you wanted to be like Donald Trump. And let's not forget before he ran for president, athletes wanted to live in Trump Tower. All the real estate guys they wanted some, you know, tee times at his golf clubs.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Most cited celebrity in rap music.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Exactly. And all the advertising executive they wanted a piece of the action. This guy was it. And the minute he runs for president he's Hitler.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: You know Trump deals with masons not free mason. All right, Juan, I know.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.sentences: Look at Juan

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: . those are like the elitist establishment versus the everyday man.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: My grandfather was a free mason, though.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: That's explain it, Dana.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: But on my mom's side.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Are you part of the trilateral.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: Rawlings, Wyoming.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Juan, I know you loved that rally. You recorded it and played it five times.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: Well, I'm just amazed. You didn't think about -- the question is the apartment.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: His apartment is better than their apartment.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: I know.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: My gosh. Not only that he's smarter, richer, he has a better apartment.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: But he also lives in the west wing.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: Oh, my God. You talk about a petty person who makes everything about him.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: That was funny. He's being funny.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: I don't think he's being funny. I think that's him. That's what the way he feels. I got a better apartment, so how come I'm not elite?

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.sentences: That's just his personality. You take everything so literally.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Let me just try to explain it. What he was trying to say that he -- he could be in that group but you love me and I love you. That's what I got out of it.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: No, no, no. I'll tell you what it was.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: It wasn't insulting to anybody.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: No, I think it was worthy of mockery, I tell you that, because my apartment is bigger than yours, my button is bigger than yours -- I mean, this is the way he talks. This is who he is. But I'm just saying, you ask about how he relates to people. You say, well, oh, these other celebrities they don't have the support of the working man. Let me just tell you something, I'm not sure he has the support of the working man on separating children from parents. I don't think he has the support of the working man -- what he does is he pushes.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: He brought them together now.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: . hot button issues and fear. And he says, you know what, you can hate Hillary Clinton. He had the crowd last night chanting lock her up, right? He can say things like, oh, go home to your mom to this guy. Why don't you get a haircut? I don't know if that's a man or a woman.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: That's a terrible impression, Juan.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: No, no, no. He hates on Clinton. He hates on everybody. And then he says, you know what, maybe those Hispanics, those immigrants, they're terrible, too. And you say.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: What's that about Hispanics? I missed that. I think he meant MS-13.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: His appeal is based on hateful language and he appeals to the worse.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: So we're all bad people. Kimberly?

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.sentences: I don't know. I think America is great. I think the president was saying that last night what an incredible country and supporters and trying to do something. He's actually followed through and had tremendous accomplishments like we reiterated numerous times on this show. And I don't know, for myself, in terms of as a Puerto Rican woman and looking at other minorities, are quite pleased. The numbers are going up in terms of -- no. In terms of their favorability about the president, yes. And you see key numbers going down, unemployment. Why wouldn't somebody be happy about that? Lower unemployment for women, for minorities, for Hispanics, for blacks, ISIS gone, we've got record job numbers.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: And Kimberly's apartment is nicer than yours.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: I bet it is. I bet it is. How about John -- remember last night, he not only was attacking Pelosi and Clinton. He then goes after John McCain.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: You did watch the rally, Juan.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: I can read.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Will President Trump's booming economy spell bad news for Nancy Pelosi and company come November? That's straight ahead.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.sentences: I like that. While the left rages about immigration, President Trump is touting the booming economy. Jobs are up, unemployment numbers are at historic lows. And small business and manufacturing confidence is surging. On the heels of this momentum the president is urging voters to back GOP candidates in November or else.

utterances.speaker: DONALD TRUMP (R), PRESIDENT OF THE UNITED STATES
utterances.sentences: We need more Republicans. We've got to get out there in the midterm. We've got to get more Republicans. We've got to get more Republicans. A vote for a Democrat for Congress is really a vote for Nancy Pelosi and her radical agenda. They want to put on more regulations. They want to take back your tax cuts, which are massive. They want to take them back, and they want to raise the hell out of your taxes, and the whole thing will go boom.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.sentences: Can't call Greg. He's nervous right now. OK, Dana.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: Well, it's certainly like even three months ago the Democrats looked to be in a much better position for the midterm elections. That has pretty much been erased. New poll today, I can't remember which poll it was, but it was a legit one showing the congressional ballot now just 6 points, where it was 15 points for Democrats in March. So something is happening there. But a couple other things I think that the Republicans should be concerned about. One is that I just watched an ad by M.J. Hegar. She's a Democrat running against a congressman, an incumbent congressman in Texas. It's one of the best ads I have ever seen. And she's a -- it's not a progressive bunch of thing. She's a veteran. She took on the Defense Department for women in combat. She's now running against a congressman, that was her congressman that said that they didn't want to meet with her, because she was not a donor. So, they're not, like, running on really progressive issues in some of these competitive districts. So the Democrats have been really smart on that. The other thing that I think that's interesting is that a new Pew poll that also was today, Republicans trusted on the economy by plus 9 over Democrats. So that's really good. Only plus 1 on trade. I think that's what's happening. But what are people talking about today, this past week, and who knows what we'll talk about next week? Immigration. And I was really surprised by this number, that Democrats have a 14-point advantage over Republicans on immigration. And I was really surprised about that.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.sentences: Yes, that's -- what do you think about that number, Jesse? Because, you know, that's double digits, right? But it's not something that can't be turned around.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Well, maybe that's depressed conservatives who are upset that the wall hasn't been built fast enough. You could see that, obviously. And on another note, the economy, if you have a good committee in a midterm election, it's going to help you. And a lot of the rejections that you've seen, I think it was 2010 with Barack Obama. That was a huge rejection of Obamacare. Or in 2006, when the Democrats swept in under President Bush, that was a rejection of all those scandals, you know, Foley and all that stuff. And a little bit of the Iraq War. I don't see an issue right now in the country where the Republicans have overreached or blown it or done something so awful that the rest of the country has to say, "Smack you in the face, and we need the Democrats to come in and take over." With the roaring economy and record-breaking consumer confidence. And safety. I mean, ISIS has been defeated. People feel safe. And the Republicans are evaluated very highly on national security. Safety and prosperity, I think, are really going to help Republicans in November.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.sentences: Yes, all right. Greg, do you want to talk about this or what you thought the block was going to be about?

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: No, but --

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.sentences: I want to be there for you.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Jesse's point, for 18 months they've been trying to find that one issue, the one issue that -- because when you -- when you decided that Donald Trump was Satan on the very first day he was president, you run the risk of running Satan fatigue. So that's why a lot of this stuff isn't sticking anymore. And it's amazing to watch the left, you know, immerse in all this good news. They're like gold panners in 1849 with a little pan. They're trying to find that one nugget of bad news. It's in here somewhere. That shows this country --

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Prospectors.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Yes, the prospectors. "I think I've got some bad news here," and they're not. And the worst thing is their confirmation bias is running out of confirmation. So all they have is their bias, which is going to lead to this cognitive dissonance, which is now building up to the point where they're calling everybody Nazis and going after Trump's kids. You are witnessing full-grade hysteria.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.sentences: All right. Juan.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: Well, I mean, it's hard to know where to start, because the conversation has gone off the rails. But let me just say that it was the Republicans who thought that the economy was really going to be their key message for the midterms and have found so far in all this special elections and even gubernatorial elections, Senate elections, it hasn't worked. Why? Because like last night in Minnesota. Here he is talking about trade, but, guess what? A place like Duluth, they're going to lose about 1,800 jobs, I should say, because of trade wars with, guess who? Canada, their neighbor to the north. You look at the stock market, the stock market's lost all of its gains, I think, on Tuesday.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.sentences: Not true.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: For the years. So it went backwards. You talk about the average tax cut for the person in Minnesota, 80 percent of Minnesotans, $700 tax cut.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Crumbs.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: So the tax cut has not had the kind of impact.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.sentences: OK.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: And then finally, you have deficits. Deficits that Republicans used to say --

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: A Democrat cares about deficits, everyone.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: Now -- Now, it --

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Here's a nugget.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: It doesn't matter.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.sentences: OK. What can I say? Two hours. Jimmy Fallon is still apologizing over a year and a half later for his funny 2016 interview with Donald Trump. What he's saying now, straight ahead.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: Welcome back. Remember this "Tonight Show" moment when then- candidate Trump paid a hair-raising visit to Jimmy Fallon?

utterances.speaker: DONALD TRUMP (R), PRESIDENT OF THE UNITED STATES
utterances.sentences: Go ahead. Give my hair a stroke. JIMMY FALLON, HOST, NBC'S "THE TONIGHT SHOW": Yes!

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: Well, apparently the late-night comedian isn't laughing about the backlash from that famous interview. The funny man opening up about his personal pain from the fallout.

utterances.speaker: FALLON
utterances.sentences: I did not do it to normalize him or to say I believed in his political beliefs or any of that stuff. It was definitely a down time, and it's tough for morale. I made a mistake. I'm sorry if I made anyone mad. And looking back, I would do it differently.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: Wow. Well, you know, sometimes in the breaks we hear things. Dana, what do you think?

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Keep it clean, Dana.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: It's one of the most funny moments in television history. People love politics and entertainment. President Trump was letting himself be vulnerable and have fun and let somebody, like, invade his personal space. Jimmy Fallon was really hilarious. And his apology reminds me of Jack Dorsey of Twitter having to apologize because he ate at Chick-Fil-A and said he liked it.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: So where is the courage, guys? I mean, you remember Nils Crane? He used to say, "If it wasn't for the starch in your shirt, there'd be nothing holding you up."

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: Kimberly, part of the problem may be that Stephen Colbert now beats Fallon regularly. And Fallon identifies --

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: In ratings.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: Yes, that's what I'm talking about. And Fallon identifies this moment as the one in which people just said, "You know, we don't like it." In fact, it looks like people who are strongly anti-Trump are the ones who've had the ratings gains.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.sentences: Yes, I mean, this is pathetic, right? It's super snowflakey. I don't know why. I mean, you know what? Why is he, like, getting -- apologizing about this? I thought that was good TV, funny. He's been telling everybody that's his hair, that it's real. So now people know.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: He got the scoop.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.sentences: I mean, he got the scoop. So, like, why not? It's just -- and the president was good-natured and fun about it. This is -- the world is getting ridiculous or more ridiculous.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: Well, wait a second, wait a second. Let's get -- let's go to the --

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.sentences: Or more ridiculous.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: -- exactly what Jimmy Fallon said. He people think he normalized Trump.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: But he doesn't share President Trump's political beliefs, and he wasn't trying to normalize him.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Well, I think it's more important to hate Trump than be funny in Hollywood, and that's sad. Because Jimmy, I believe, is probably the most talented late-night guy.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.sentences: Right.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: I think he is probably the wittiest and the smartest, and I look forward to doing his show one day.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: I knew it. I knew it.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.sentences: Oh, my God.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: It's book preservation.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: But in all seriousness, I mean, there's show business and then there's politics. This is not "Meet the Press." Trump went on there. He knew he wasn't going to get grilled. Fallon knew he was going to have fun, and that's fine. It's OK to do that. I could have Hillary on my show, and I could tousel her hair, and I could make jokes.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: No, you can't.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.sentences: Please don't. Going to normalize Hillary?

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: And people would do that. Or I could grill her about Benghazi, and then she'd give me boring canned answers. Sometimes there's a time when you don't listen to the audience. You just do what you feel is right.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: So Greg, I remember, I think it was Bill Clinton on Arsenio Hall. And people were saying, "Oh, why are you doing -- why is this playing the sax there?" Or you think about some of the interviews, Anthony Bourdain having beers in Vietnam with Obama. He's "Oh, gosh," you know, or going hunting with the guy the --

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.sentences: Bear Grylls.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: Yes. So -- and people -- people -- the conservatives went nuts. "Oh, no. This guy is using media." Remember that?

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Yes, I wasn't part of that. So anyway, it's kind of sad in Hollywood. Politics just isn't personal. It's also a survival mechanism, and that's what he's figuring out. But what he -- the phrase that is being overused these days is "normalized." People say that a lot: "You can't normalize 'X' or 'Y'." Normalizing Trump as though he's polio --

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: Right.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: -- or, you know, he's murder. And it's -- it was cowardly and sad. I really like Jimmy Fallon. But that was probably the lowest point that his life has been in.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.sentences: I think so.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: And he's pretty wild.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.sentences: He should have gone back -- he used to have some conservatives talk to him. He was so funny and talented.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Oh, my God. How sad. Normal -- oh.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.sentences: But now -- look what happens. Now he's --

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Get him a therapy llama.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.sentences: Very sad.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: All right. Is a "latte liberal" just a clever jab, or is there finally evidence to back it up? The answer ahead on "The Five."

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: It turns out the phrase "latte liberal" is based in reality. A new study from the University of Pennsylvania finds liberals do, in fact, drink more lattes than conservatives. It's apparently all because of the drink's Italian heritage. Researchers say liberals are more open to foreign products and globalization, while conservatives embrace products perceived to be made in America.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.sentences: Like the Big Mac.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Like the Big -- Le Big Mac. Kimberly, also interesting, they say for fast food, liberals prefer Chipotle and Panera. Conservatives prefer Sonic and Hardee's. What do you make of that?

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.sentences: Wow, that's kind of funny. Maybe there's some, you know, science to it, so to speak, and like, they take random surveys or whatever. I know that Greg used to eat Chipotle until he became deadly ill due to his lack of intestinal fortitude.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: I don't think I was the only one who became deathly ill at Chipotle. But I agree with this. Conservatives don't take risks. And at my age mixing milk with coffee is, indeed, a risk.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.sentences: For everyone around.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: But I should also add coffee should only be taken black. It's not coffee if you put milk or sugar in it. Then that's a kid's drink.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: You are such a manly man.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: No, it's -- coffee is --

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: That is the only manly thing do you.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: It's beautiful. Black -- there's nothing better than black coffee.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: All right. Well, now I feel very effeminate --

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: In a tin cup.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: -- because I drink it with milk and sugar, Dana. Beer --

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: Yes, that's pretty pathetic.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: All right.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.sentences: You're getting a little soft these days.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: I am getting a little soft. I know. Beers, liberals prefer Heineken and Guinness, imports. Conservatives, Budweiser and Miller.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: I mean, I'm more of a Coors girl, myself.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: The Rocky Mountain.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: Colorado, yes. And we also have Keystone Light. I don't know if they still make that, but we sure like that.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: That's some cheap beer, Dana. And in terms of activities, Juan, liberals do yoga and martial arts, whereas conservatives, archery and woodworking. I do neither of those. But go ahead.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: No, I think, you know, great. Drink -- everybody seems to like coffee, period.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: Both sides. So, what struck me was the commonality, you know, that hey, there's something everybody likes.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: We could have a coffee summit.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: Yes, I think we should have a coffee --

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: At Starbucks.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: And the other point of it was that someone pointed out that, even with lattes, it's better for the American economy, because it benefits the dairy industry. And I didn't realize this. They said coffee beans are grown in several American states. It's not a foreign product. So if you go to Hawaii, Puerto Rico, California, coffee beans.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: That's --

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Well, I'm still reeling from being called a weakling by drinking coffee with milk and sugar.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: That's OK. It's OK.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: It's OK. I feel better about it.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.sentences: You do other stuff.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: Can somebody Photoshop that, please?

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Also, smart phones, liberals prefer the iPhone. Conservatives, Samsung. Now, I just don't know what the deal is with that.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.sentences: I'm going to say that's --

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: I'm beginning to call bologna on this whole thing.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.sentences: Yes, this is not good.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Is this study --

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: I actually think this is true. I mean, I do have an iPhone. But I think that a lot of -- it's almost like conservatives don't like the herd mentality so much. I'm going to get hate mail on that, right? But Apple became such an icon of liberalness. Right? So then they went with the Samsung, and they think it's better. And the wars between people who have iPhones or Samsungs, they're real.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: I don't -- the reason why I call bologna on this, I don't think politics has anything to do with these choices. It's just something that they do.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: Just happens?

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Yes. It just happens. I don't think about it.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: The other part of it is age. I think if you had a cohort of liberals, you're going to find they're much younger. A cohort of conservatives, they're much older.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: True.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: And you're going to find the conservatives, the older end of that cohort has more disposable income than the younger.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: So --

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: How did that surprise you?

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: I always think conservatives have more disposable income, because we're smarter with money. "One More Thing" is up next.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: It's time now for "One More Thing." I'll go first. Last week Iran's World Cup team won their first game since 1998. And this week, Tehran's Provisional Council made a last-minute decision allowing women to attend the screening of the game in Tehran's largest stadium. It's the first time they've been allowed to do that since 1979. Iran lost to Spain 0-1, so not a high scoring game. But women still celebrated. Many hope this will lead to permanently reversing their ban. So glad to see them get to go.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Did Trump have something to do with that?

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: I'm sure he did. I'm sure he did. All right. Juan.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: So big news from New Zealand. The Kiwi prime minister had a baby today. That's right. Jacinda Ardern had a baby girl. She becomes only the second world leader to give birth while in office. The first, Pakistan's Benazir Bhutto in 1990. And in an interesting twist of fate, today is also Bhutto's birthday. Ardern is not married. Her partner, a TV news presenter, plans to be a stay-at-home dad. One Kiwi commentator said it was a historic moment, because the birth shows that pregnant women can do their jobs. Ardern is taking a six-week maternity leave. Congratulations to all.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: All right. Jesse.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: I would like to wish Steven Watters, my father, a very happy 70th birthday.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.sentences: Happy birthday.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: Happy birthday, dad.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: There is dear old dad. Look how dapper he was. Now everybody knows where I get it from. That's him playing lacrosse. All-American lacrosse player. It was very cold there in his shadow growing up. And there he is with my mom taking a selfie. Probably the first selfie ever, back in the 60's.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Funniest thing I've ever heard.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: And now he has a huge beard. I've never seen him without a beard. I have no idea what he looks like. And there he is with Ann Watters, "Mom Texts," as we know her. So Dad, happy birthday, I love you very much.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: Happy birthday.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Congratulations.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: Happy birthday.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: How sweet.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.sentences: Happy birthday.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: Kimberly.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.sentences: -- to you. Yes. OK, so this is super cute. I love the little nostalgic things, parents and sons. So this is a father and son cop duo, and there's a photo we can show you, so adorable. So this is a 20-year-old photo. And what happened is the 1998 photo shows Officer Andy Golden and his son Michael inside the police cruiser. And you fast forward to the photo taken this past Father's Day, shows him seated in the same position but at 6'7". Can you imagine? So the father and son police officers.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Don't try that at home.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.sentences: Said to make the photo redo was a hard squeeze. While they're not partners, his son followed in his footsteps into law enforcement, which is incredible, at the Auburn Police Department. And it's cute, because the original caption said, "When I get bigger, I'm going to be my dad's partner and catch bad guys and burglars."

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Nice.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.sentences: Isn't that cute?

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Very cool.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: And at that height, he'll probably have an advantage.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.sentences: I think it's adorable.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: Greg, do you feel jealous about that height?

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.sentences: Oh, my God.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: I wish I had a "One More Thing" about a world leader having a baby. Instead, I have gifts from the legendary band, The Misfits, who are big fans of "The Five."

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.sentences: Oh, wow.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: So everybody gets a Misfits shirt.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Thank you.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Even Juan. Juan, I know you love The Misfits.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: I don't even know them.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Wait, is this --

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: They're from New Jersey. They're amazing. Legendary Jerry Only gave them. His mom is a dedicated watcher.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: I've never worn anything like this.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: I can't wait to see Dana in a Misfits T-shirt.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: This will scare people.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: I have a second "One More Thing."

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: OK.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Let's go to it.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.sentences: Of course do you, diva.

utterances.speaker: GRAPHIC
utterances.sentences: Greg's Breaking Wind News

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: "Greg's Breaking Wind News."

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.sentences: What?

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Not breaking news, breaking wind news. This is the greatest video of all time. A giant gust of wind in Commerce, Colorado -- Commerce City, Colorado, sent a porta potty into the sky. Look at that. It's like a time machine.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: Was it empty?

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: It's like -- it's like, I don't know. Was it Dr. No? No, Dr. Who. It just flies in the air. And anyway, no one was hurt. We always have to say that. No one was hurt.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: You know, I grew up not far from there, and in the summertime in the afternoons, the winds really does pick up. You have a lot of tornado warnings, things like that.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: Yes. It's like Dorothy. It's like "The Wizard of Oz."

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Exactly.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: Except you're in a port-a-potty.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: It was a cheap version of "Wizard of Oz." A really cheap version.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: Wonder where that outhouse landed on. Oh, my gosh. All right. Well, that was a great show, everybody. Thank you so much.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Everybody, wear their shirts.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: Yes. I will wear my shirt in private. Set your DVRs and never miss an episode of "The Five." "Special Report" is up next. Hey, John.

utterances.speaker: JOHN ROBERTS, FOX NEWS
utterances.sentences: We are definitely not in Kansas anymore. Thanks, Dana.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
